Since it was first reported in 2012, copper-based molecular catalysts for water oxidation have gained significant attention. While investigations have endeavored to elucidate additional copper molecular catalysts for water oxidation and enhance their catalytic activities, few have systematically explored substituents' impact on their water oxidation performance. In this work, a series of copper-bipyridine catalysts, (2,2′-bipyridine)Cu(OH)2 derivatives with various substituents were synthesized by simply mixing the copper salts with 4,4′-R-2,2′-bipyridine ligands, where R represents seven distinct substituents. The UV–vis and FTIR spectra confirm the successful synthesis of the catalysts. However, only four of them are stable under the experimental conditions. The electrochemical studies show that their water oxidation potential follows the order of Cu-H < Cu-CH3 < Cu–OCH3 < Cu-CH2OH, indicating their water oxidation ability. Computation calculation indicates a linear relationship between the turnover frequency and the HOMO-LUMO energy gap. This work uncovers the influence of substituents on the catalytic properties of copper-bipyridine catalysts, offering valuable insights into the rational design of copper-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Water oxidation Copper complexes Catalysis Ligand modification Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Driven by the energy crisis and environmental pressures, scientists are seeking to harness solar energy and convert it into chemical energy that can be used directly [1–3]. This endeavour assumes profound significance in the context of addressing the imperatives of sustainable human existence and development. Artificial photosynthesis is considered to be an effective approach to dissolving the above issues [4–6]. The water oxidation half-reaction is conspicuously recognized as the principal bottleneck of artificial photosynthesis [7–9], presenting a formidable challenge for researchers. To overcome its energy barriers, various efficient homogeneous metal-based catalysts were developed, such as ruthenium-type catalysts [10,11], iridium-type catalysts [12], rhenium-type catalysts [13], and osmium-type catalysts [14,15], etc. Although precious metal derivatives have exhibited remarkable catalytic activities, their practical application has been impeded by inherent drawbacks, such as their prohibitively high cost and susceptibility to undesirable instabilities [16,17]. In recent years, there has emerged a burgeoning interest in copper-based catalysts, driven by their distinctive economic advantages, biocompatibility, and the rich panoply of valence states inherent to copper (Cu0, Cu+, Cu2+, and Cu3+) [18–20]. This trajectory in research underscores their potential as promising candidates for overcoming the challenges associated with the water oxidation half-reaction in artificial photosynthesis. In 2012, Meyer and co-workers found that a copper–bipyridine catalyst, (bpy)Cu(OH)2, can be rapidly formed from commercially available copper salts and bipyridine at alkaline conditions [21]. Cyclic voltammetry of this catalyst showed large irreversible currents at about 1.5 V vs. NHE. The overpotential is about 0.75 V vs. NHE and the TOF is estimated to be 100 s−1 at its optimal pH conditions. Based on this work, Lin and co-workers modified the bipyridine ligand with two pendant hydroxyl groups on the 6,6′-position. The newly made catalyst, (6,6′-OH-2,2′-bipyridine)Cu(OH)2, showed a much lower overpotential at 0.64 V vs. NHE. Experimental and computational studies demonstrated that the hydroxyl groups assisted the proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process, resulting in high water oxidation activity [22]. Subsequently, Stott et al. reported that by simply replacing the bipyridine in (bpy)Cu(OH)2 with pyridyl imidazole, the resulting copper catalyst, Cu(pimH) where pimH = 2-(2′-pyridyl)-imidazole), can have a 0.15 V lower onset potential [23]. This is due to the deprotonated imidazole ring having a strong σ-donor effect, enriching electrons around CuII, resulting in a lower potential to CuIII in the catalytic cycle. Previous studies on ruthenium-based molecular catalysts revealed that the σ-acceptor inhibits the catalytic activity and increases the catalytic turnover numbers (TONs); on the contrary, the presence of σ-donor accelerates the catalytic rate while decreasing the stability of the catalyst [24–28]. Zeng et al. discussed the effect of electron-donating/ accepting substituents on the catalytic activity of mononuclear ruthenium complexes for water oxidation [29]. Inspired by the above studies, we intended to systematically study the substituents' effect on the properties of copper–bipyridine catalysts in this work. Herein, we prepared seven copper-bipyridine catalysts, (4,4′-R-2,2′-bipyridine)Cu(OH)2, with different R groups - i.e., NH2, OCH3, CH3, H, CH2OH, Cl, and Br at the para position of the bipyridine ligand (as shown in Scheme 1 ). The pendant substituents are designed to change the electronic environment of the metal center, thereby changing the oxygen-evolving activity. The strategy of using electron-donating / -accepting groups to change the features of copper complexes has been utilized before [30,31]. However, their effect on the water oxidation activity of copper-bipyridine catalysts has not been explored. We observed that complexes with the electron-accepting groups (Cl, Br) are not stable at pH 12.5 buffers. The TOF for stable samples with electron-donating groups is lower than [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]. Assisted by the DFT calculations, a negative linear relationship between the TOF and HOMO-LUMO energy gap was observed. The results presented here clarified the electronic environmental impact on the properties of (bpy)Cu(OH)2 derivatives and provided insights into designing molecular catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthetic procedures The catalysts in this study were prepared according to the literature (as shown in Scheme 2 ) [21]. The Cu complexes, [Cu(bpy-R)(OH)2](OAc)2 were synthesized by mixing 4 mmol 2,2′-bipyridyl derivatives and 4 mmol Cu(OAc)2, and stirred in 30 mL methanol for 9 h. Then the solution was concentrated to ∼5 mL and filter it to give rise to the blueish solid, which was further washed with methanol (5 mL*3) and dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 4 h, as the final product. The colors of the powders are shown in Fig. S1, Supporting Information. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) was performed with a Thermo ScientificTM Q ExactiveTM Mass Spectrometer using methanol as the eluent (Figs. S2–S5, Supporting Information). In methanol, the complexes are in dimer states, [(bpy-R)Cu(μ-OH)]2, which are consistent with previous conclusions [21,32,33]. 2.2 Spectroscopy measurements Infrared spectroscopy was measured with a Perkin Elmer's SPE CTRUM 100 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer. Electronic absorption spectra were recorded with a UV-visible Shimadzu-2700i diode-array spectrophotometer and were corrected for the background spectrum of the solvent. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) and square wave voltammograms (SWVs) were measured with a CH Instruments CHI-760E bipotentiostat at ambient temperature (21–24 °C) in a single compartment cell with a 3.0 mm glassy carbon disc working electrode, platinum wire counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) reference electrode [34]. The reference electrode was calibrated with the [Fe(CN)6]3‑/ [Fe(CN)6]4‑ couple [35]. Electrochemical data were calibrated with respect to the NHE by incorporating a voltage shift of 0.199 V to the recorded potential measurements. All potentials are expressed in relation to NHE, unless explicitly indicated otherwise. Solutions contained 1 mM analyte in aqueous solution containing 0.1 M buffer solutions. The buffer solution was prepared by initially combining 0.1 M NaOH and 0.1 M NaOAc solutions, followed by precise pH adjustment using the respective acid or base to achieve the desired pH. 2.4 Spectroelectrochemistry UV−vis spectroelectrochemical data for the copper complexes were obtained using the above-mentioned CH Instruments CHI-760E bipotentiostat coupled to an UV-visible Agilent Carry60 spectrophotometer and were corrected for the background spectrum of the solvent (i.e. 0.1 M pH NaOH/NaOAc buffers). A standard three-electrode setup was used. The working electrode was a Pt honeycomb microelectrode with a Pt counter electrode and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode. Then the absorption spectrum was recorded at a certain period when holding the applied potentials at 1.15 V vs NHE. 2.5 DFT calculations The quantum chemical calculations for Cu-R (R=H, CH3, OCH3, CH2OH) were conducted by using the density functional theory (DFT) in the Gaussian 09 software suite [36–39]. These computations involved the optimization of closed-shell electronic structure complexes at the unrestricted level. For all Cu catalysts, the DFT calculations were carried out using the B3LYP functional, while a mixed basis set was employed, with def2-TZVP being utilized for the copper atom and 6–311G** for the remaining constituent atoms. Following the completion of these calculations, the obtained output files were further analyzed using the Multiwfn program, which facilitated the extraction of orbital information and the determination of the HOMO-LUMO energy gap values for all Cu-R complexes [40]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Spectroscopy properties The IR spectrum is shown in Fig. S6, Supporting Information. Compared with the pristine Cu(OAc)2 salt, the appearance of a peak at 1020 cm−1 was attributed to the Cu-N characteristic vibration [41], suggesting the successful coordinating reactions between Cu ions and N atoms in bipyridine-type ligands. The board peaks between 3000∼3600 cm−1 assigned to OH vibrations from the coordinated OH group and water. Previous studies have shown that the [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]-type catalysts have distinct broad bimodal peaks of UV/Vis at around 305 nm [21,22]. To further prove the successful synthesis of catalysts in this study, the UV/Vis absorption spectra of copper complexes and their corresponding ligands were measured in methanol, as shown in Fig. S7, Supporting Information. We found that the ligands have a typical single peak at around 278–295 nm, while the catalysts show red-shifted character with bimodal peaks at 305 nm. In accordance with the findings reported by Mayer, the optimal conditions for [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]-type catalysts are established within the pH range of 11.8 to 13.3 in a buffered solution [21]. Hence, the UV/Vis spectra of all catalysts were measured in this study in pH 12.5 NaOH/NaOAc buffer solution. As shown in Fig. 1 , the UV/Vis absorption profiles in both buffer solution and methanol exhibit pronounced similarities for catalysts bearing substituents such as –OCH3, -CH3, -H, and -CH2OH. However, the catalysts featuring -NH2, -Cl, and -Br as substituents either exhibited limited solubility or underwent decomposition within the experimental conditions, as the formation of a white flocculent precipitate were found immediately after adding the buffer solution (shown in Fig. S8, Supporting Information). The notable disappearance of UV/Vis spectra peaks centered around 305 nm proves the non-existence of copper complexes. Therefore, these catalysts were excluded from further examination in subsequent sections of this study. In order to assess the catalysts' resilience in alkaline environments, i.e. the experimental conditions in this study, the UV/Vis spectra of Cu–OCH3, Cu-CH3, Cu-H, and Cu-CH2OH were recorded following their dissolution in a pH 12.5 buffer solution, with observations conducted at 0 h, 10 h, 24 h, and 48 h. As illustrated in Fig. S9 (Supporting Information), the UV/Vis spectra for all the catalysts under examination remained remarkably consistent, displaying only marginal variations over the specified duration. Additionally, the visual appearance of the solutions remained unchanged even after prolonged exposure to the buffer for a duration of 48 h. These results provide robust substantiation for the subsequent evaluation of its catalytic performance. 3.2 Electrochemical properties The electrochemical behaviors for [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]2+ have long been known. Mayer and co-workers have previously demonstrated the optimal pH for electrocatalysis to be 12.5. Given the potential impact of electron-donating groups on the electronic properties of the copper center, cyclic voltammograms (CV) and square wave voltammetry (SWV) were undertaken within a diverse range of pH buffer solutions spanning from 12.0 to 12.6. As clearly shown in Fig. S10 (Supporting Information), the CVs exhibit large, irreversible, and notably pH-dependent oxidative waves that correspond to the catalytic water oxidation process. Inspiring by previous studies, an in-depth analysis of pH-dependent variations in currents and water oxidation potentials were undertaken in the pH range of 12.0–12.6 as illustrated in Fig. S11. For instance, the Cu-CH3 catalyst demonstrates a catalytic current of 411 μA at pH 12.4. This current can be enhanced to 621 μA at pH 12.5 by slightly sacrificing the catalytic driving force from 1.61 V to 1.64 V. However, further augmenting the catalytic current to 771 μA requires an increase in the potential to an undesirable 1.73 V. Although the catalytic currents for all samples reach their maximum at pH 12.6, their required driving force are much higher than those at pH 12.5. Considering both catalytic currents and water oxidation potentials for all samples, pH 12.5 was selected as the optimal buffer condition, consistent with prior reports [21]. Subsequently, the CVs of pure pH 12.5 buffer solution and Cu(OAc)2 in pH 12.5 buffer solution were measured. Notably, these CVs did not manifest any observable water oxidation wave within the measured range, signifying the pivotal role of the Cu-R catalysts in driving the catalytic activity, as exemplified in Fig. S12, Supporting Information. The SWVs of all samples in different pH buffer solutions were also recorded due to its heightened sensitivity in pinpointing the precise positions of redox peaks [15]. A discernible pH-dependent peak within the voltage range of 0.99 to 1.03 V was consistently observed for all samples, as depicted in Fig. 2 . This electrochemical feature can be ascribed to the Cu(III)/Cu(II) redox pair, as reported by Mayer and Lin [42]. Furthermore, a larger peak at 1.27 V was also observed for all samples except [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]. We attribute this particular peak to the Cu(IV)/Cu(III) redox pair, a postulation that accords with previously established thermodynamic pathways reported by Lin and co-workers [20]. However, the peak at 1.27 V disappeared for [(bpy)Cu(OH)2] because it doesn't go through the Cu(III) to Cu(IV) transition [22]. This can be attributed to its low water oxidation potential. The third prominent pH-dependent peak, extending from 1.32 to 1.63 V, is unequivocally associated with the catalytic water oxidation potentials. These three typical peaks under different pH conditions were summarized in Table 1 . Based on the above results, we proposed thermodynamic pathways for the Cu-R complex (shown in Fig. 3 ), consistent with Lin and co-workers’ calculation results [20]. We investigated the spectroelectrochemical one-electron oxidation behaviors of Cu(II) for these catalysts, with an applied potential of 1.15 V vs NHE (Scheme 3 , S13). The identical transformation features of Cu(III)/Cu(II) were observed, where Cu(II) shows two absorption peaks at 298 nm and 308 nm while Cu(III) shows an absorption peak at 279 nm. The generation of Cu(III) was considered completed once the absorption at 308 nm stopped increasing with applying potential. Figs. 3b and S13 show the absorbance changes during the spectroelectrochemical process. They exhibited similar transformation rates. This as far as we know, is the first time showing the Cu(III)/Cu(II) transformation for [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]-type catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of four catalysts at the scan rate of 100 mV−1 at pH = 12.5. Obviously, the water oxidation potential of Cu-H is the lowest (at 1.53 V vs NHE) and the rest water oxidation potentials are in the order of Cu-CH3 < Cu–OCH3 < Cu-CH2OH. Detailed characteristic potentials are summarized in Table 2 . The onset potential demonstrates a similar trend, i.e. Cu-H and Cu-CH3 own lower onset potential at 0.97 while Cu–OCH3 and Cu-CH2OH show higher potential at around 1.00 V. The higher overpotential for water oxidation can be induced by the higher ligand oxidation potentials, as shown in Fig. S14 [3,22,43]. This can be further explained by the DFT calculations in the subsequent section. 3.3 Catalytic performances To better understand the difference in their electrocatalytic activities, the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated from CVs. Figs. 5a and S15 show the CVs collected at different scan rates. The TOF can be estimated according to equation 1–3 based on previous studies [21,44]. (1) i d = 0.4633 nFA c c a t n F v D R T (2) i c a t = n c a t FA c c a t k c a t D (3) i c a t i d = 1.424 k c a t v In these equations, n is the number of electrons transferred in the uncatalyzed reaction (CuII/I reduction, n = 1), F is the Faraday's constant (F = 96,485 C/mol), A is the area of the working electrode (A = 0.07 cm2), ccat is the bulk concentration of the catalyst, D is the diffusion coefficient, R is the gas constant, T is the absolute temperature, ncat is the number of electrons transferred during the process in which the catalytic reaction occurs, hence ncat is 4, and kcat is the apparent first-order rate constant [45,46], which is often used to evaluate the water oxidation performance for molecular catalysts [47]. By plotting icat/id versus V−1/2, we can evaluate the kcat by the slop, which is around 1.86 s−1 for Cu-H. Though these evaluation methods may not be accurate to reflect their real TOFs but can be used to compare their relative values. The TOF for Cu-CH3, Cu–OCH3, and Cu-CH2OH are 1.76 s−1, 1.52 s−1, and 1.44 s−1, respectively. This again follows a trend of TOF (H) > TOF (CH3) > TOF (OCH3) > TOF (CH2OH), the same trend as the catalytic voltage, which shows the impact of substituents on copper-based molecular catalysts. Control potential electrolysis (CPE) experiments were conducted to measure the electrochemical oxygen generation of catalyst Cu-H. The experiments were carried out at a potential of 1.45 V versus NHE reference electrode, using a glassy carbon electrode in a 0.1 M NaOAc/NaOH solution at pH = 12.5 (Fig. S16, Supporting Information). The experiment lasted for 1 h and the total amount of charge that passed through the electrode was about 0.18 C. Considering the small amount of generated oxygen, we found it difficult to measure oxygen by gas chromatography. Instead, we utilized the electrochemical detection O2 method, which relies on the reduction of O2 [48]. As shown in Fig. S17, the CV scans clearly show the identical characteristics of O2. The extraordinarily large current after CPE confirms the generation of O2. A CPE experiment under the same condition without catalysts was also performed. The total amount of charge that passed through the electrode was only 0.08 C, a much smaller value than the ones with the catalyst (Fig. S18). The CV scan also indicates a negligible amount of oxygen was generated, showing the important role of copper complexes in water oxidation (Fig. S19). The UV−vis spectra and CV before and after electrolysis were performed to examine the catalyst stability. Figs. S20 and S21 illustrate the complexes were not decomposed after the CPE experiments. To examine the possible deposition of Cu-based film on the electrode, the glassy carbon surface was analyzed after the CPE experiment (Fig. S22, Supporting Information). There is little to no signal observed after 1 h of electrolysis, demonstrating that little copper complex was deposited on the electrode surface. 3.4 DFT calculations Ligand modification of molecular catalysts has always been an important method for modification studies of molecular catalysts [49–51]. The impact of modified ligands on the catalytic efficacy of molecular catalysts fundamentally arises from factors such as the acid-base characteristics of functional groups, electron-donating and electron-absorbing capabilities, electronegativity, and related attributes. The above results show that the trend of electrocatalytic activity of Cu-R is not dependent on the substituents’ electron-donating ability. In particular, the catalytic performance of Cu-H and Cu-CH2OH are quite different even though they have the same σp. Hence, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to understand the catalytic performance difference. At the quantum chemical level, it is widely acknowledged that the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) characterizes the electron-donating capacity, while the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) represents the electron-accepting capability [52]. The variance in electronegativity between the metal and ligand surfaces induces electron transfer between them [53]. Fig. S23 shows the calculated LUMO and HOMO electron density distributions. The previous reports have revealed the relationships between the HOMO–LUMO gaps and the properties of complexes [54–56]. The DFT calculations unequivocally underscore the profound influence of the HOMO-LUMO energy gap on the water oxidation performance of Cu-R. This energy differential stands as a pivotal parameter characterizing the chemical reactivity and kinetic stability of the molecular entity, as depicted in Fig. 6 . The observation aligns with the experimental cyclic voltammetry data and explains why Cu-CH3 and the parent Cu-H have higher TOFs. This association is underpinned by the fundamental principle that a substantial HOMO−LUMO energy gap engenders an energetically unfavorable procedure encompassing the introduction of electrons into a relatively high-energy LUMO, the removal of electrons from a lower-energy HOMO, and thus, the creation of the activated complex in any prospective reaction [50]. Remarkably, this observation is in exact alignment with our experimental findings. To further investigate the impact of free energy on their catalytic behaviors [57], the optimized structures for CuIV-oxo species in Scheme 3 are also calculated as shown in Figs. S24–S27 and data was summarized in Table S2. The calculated data is consistent with the previous report by Lin et al. [22]. The free energy of CuIV-oxo species for Cu-H is the smallest while Cu–OCH3 and Cu-CH2OH have a larger free energy (Fig. S28). This could partially explain the smaller redox potential and the faster TOF value for the Cu-H complex compared to other complexes. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study focused on the modification of the [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]2+-type molecular catalysts (Cu-R) through the introduction of various substituents. Our initial intent was to introduce both electron-donating (CH3, OCH3, NH2) and electron-withdrawing (Cl and Br) groups. Nevertheless, UV–vis spectroscopic outcomes indicated that catalysts featuring Cl, Br, and NH2 substitutions are unstable within a highly alkaline environment, while those with CH3, H, OCH3, and CH2OH substituents exhibited stability in pH 12.5 buffer solutions for 48 h. Subsequent electrochemical investigations into Cu-R (R=H, CH3, OCH3, and CH2OH) unveiled that Cu-H exhibited the lowest water oxidation potential and the highest TOF among the studied samples, while Cu-CH2OH exhibited the counterpart behavior. This is thought-provoking considering -H and -CH2OH are both non-electron-withdrawing or -donating groups, illustrating tuning the catalytic performance of molecular catalysts is a complex process. The significance of this study lies in several key aspects: (1) Square Wave Voltammetry (SWV) provided a clear delineation of the thermodynamic pathways for the [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]2+-type molecular catalysts for the first time; (2) spectroelectrochemical findings confirm the transformation of Cu(III)/Cu(II); (3) DFT calculations successfully explained the changing of potentials and TOFs for water oxidation. It is important to note that while this study was centered on the [(bpy)Cu(OH)2]2+-type catalysts, the implications of substituents on water oxidation potential and TOFs can be extended to other systems, offering an effective strategy for the fine-tuning of catalytic behaviors in molecular catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Since it was first reported in 2012, copper-based molecular catalysts for water oxidation have gained significant attention. While investigations have endeavored to elucidate additional copper molecular catalysts for water oxidation and enhance their catalytic activities, few have systematically explored substituents' impact on their water oxidation performance. In this work, a series of copper-bipyridine catalysts, (2,2′-bipyridine)Cu(OH)2 derivatives with various substituents were synthesized by simply mixing the copper salts with 4,4′-R-2,2′-bipyridine ligands, where R represents seven distinct substituents. The UV–vis and FTIR spectra confirm the successful synthesis of the catalysts. However, only four of them are stable under the experimental conditions. The electrochemical studies show that their water oxidation potential follows the order of Cu-H < Cu-CH3 < Cu–OCH3 < Cu-CH2OH, indicating their water oxidation ability. Computation calculation indicates a linear relationship between the turnover frequency and the HOMO-LUMO energy gap. This work uncovers the influence of substituents on the catalytic properties of copper-bipyridine catalysts, offering valuable insights into the rational design of copper-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of substituents on the water oxidation performance for copper–bipyridine catalysts
